cluster_classes.class_description: Processes and channels that enable the spread and rapid transmission of information, particularly in the context of how stories or legends propagate through society.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Advancements in technology and communication platforms enable rapid transmission of information and proliferation of urban legends.

members.entity_description: Improvements in technological capabilities and tools that enable faster and broader dissemination of information, including urban legends.
Means of transmitting information, identified as enabling faster spread of urban legends.
The fast spread and sharing of information enabled by modern communication channels.
Various online and offline communication channels and media used to share stories and information, such as websites, apps, and broadcast media.

cluster_classes.class_description: Networked digital channels that enable rapid, wide dissemination of content to large audiences, such as the internet and social media platforms.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: In the age of the internet and social media, stories can be shared and disseminated at lightning speed.

members.entity_description: Global digital network described as a medium that accelerates sharing of stories and legends.
Online platforms that allow rapid, wide dissemination of urban legend stories.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes involved in how stories are communicated and change over time, including oral sharing, passing between generations, and gradual adaptation.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: shared orally, passed down from one generation to the next, and evolved over time

members.entity_description: The practice of sharing tales verbally and passing them between generations.
Passing stories from one generation to the next within a culture.
The gradual change and adaptation of stories over time.

cluster_classes.class_description: People who receive, engage with, and reflect on stories such as urban legends, whether as individual listeners or collective audiences.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: People who hear and reflect on urban legends; groups of listeners or readers captivated by urban legends.

members.entity_description: People who hear and reflect on urban legends and other stories.
Groups of listeners or readers who engage with and are captivated by urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Social and economic mechanisms that link societies and enable the spread of stories, ideas, and legends across regions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: As societies became more interconnected through trade and travel, urban legends began to spread across regions and continents.

members.entity_description: Societies linked through trade and travel, facilitating the spread of legends.
Exchange of goods and services that contributes to cross-cultural contact.
Movement of people between places that helps spread stories and legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Broad geographic units used to describe where phenomena, such as urban legends, spread or occur, including regions and continents.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: urban legends began to spread across regions and continents

members.entity_description: Geographical areas across which urban legends spread.
Large landmasses mentioned as destinations for spreading urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Groups of people described as worldwide recipients or bearers of stories and legends. Includes any phrasing that denotes a global population or audience.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: people around the world; global audience who can receive urban legends

members.entity_description: Global population whose imagination and curiosity are captured by urban legends.
Worldwide collection of people who can receive urban legends via internet and social media.

cluster_classes.class_description: Entities that describe how widely narratives or legends are spread, emphasizing global or large-scale reach.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: stories can be shared and disseminated at lightning speed, reaching a global audience ... around the world

members.entity_description: Global scope of dissemination of the Hook Man story.
Narratives, including urban legends, that can be quickly shared online to many people.

args.new_description: Individuals and groups who receive, listen to, or engage with stories and urban legends, from specific listeners to global audiences.
args.justification: Both classes describe the same conceptual role (recipients of stories) differing only in scale (local listeners vs global audience), so they should be unified into a single Story Audiences class.

splits.name: Stories and Legends
splits.description: Narrative content such as stories and urban legends that can be transmitted through various media to different audiences.

args.justification: ClsC_8e4324ae currently mixes a spatial dissemination qualifier ('around the world') with a content entity ('stories'); separating the narrative content into its own class yields cleaner semantics.

args.new_description: Individuals and groups who receive, listen to, or engage with stories and urban legends, from specific listeners to global audiences.
args.justification: Assign a coherent Class_Group tying audiences to the broader dissemination schema and confirm the merged class metadata.
Information Dissemination Mechanisms describes processes and channels that spread stories, fitting within the shared dissemination and reach Class_Group.
Digital Communication Media (internet, social media) are core technological channels for story dissemination and should share the dissemination and reach Class_Group.
Story Transmission Processes (oral storytelling, intergenerational transmission, evolution of tales) are narrative dissemination processes and belong in the same dissemination-focused Class_Group.
Cross-Cultural Connectivity (trade, travel, interconnected societies) represents social mechanisms enabling stories to spread geographically, aligning with the dissemination and reach Class_Group.
Geographic Areas (regions, continents) are used specifically as the spatial frame for how widely stories spread, so they should be grouped under the same dissemination and reach Class_Group.

args.new_description: Qualifiers that describe the global or large-scale spatial scope over which narratives or legends are disseminated.
args.justification: After splitting out narrative content, this class now cleanly represents spatial scope qualifiers (e.g., 'around the world') and should be renamed and grouped accordingly.

args.new_description: Narrative content such as stories and urban legends that are disseminated through various channels to different audiences.
args.justification: The new split-out content class represents the narratives being disseminated and should be explicitly named and linked into the same dissemination Class_Group.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes describe the same conceptual role (recipients of stories) differing only in scale (local listeners vs global audience), so they should be unified into a single Story Audiences class.
ClsC_8e4324ae currently mixes a spatial dissemination qualifier ('around the world') with a content entity ('stories'); separating the narrative content into its own class yields cleaner semantics.

executed_decisions.new_description: Individuals and groups who receive, listen to, or engage with stories and urban legends, from specific listeners to global audiences.
executed_decisions.justification: Assign a coherent Class_Group tying audiences to the broader dissemination schema and confirm the merged class metadata.
Information Dissemination Mechanisms describes processes and channels that spread stories, fitting within the shared dissemination and reach Class_Group.
Digital Communication Media (internet, social media) are core technological channels for story dissemination and should share the dissemination and reach Class_Group.
Story Transmission Processes (oral storytelling, intergenerational transmission, evolution of tales) are narrative dissemination processes and belong in the same dissemination-focused Class_Group.
Cross-Cultural Connectivity (trade, travel, interconnected societies) represents social mechanisms enabling stories to spread geographically, aligning with the dissemination and reach Class_Group.
Geographic Areas (regions, continents) are used specifically as the spatial frame for how widely stories spread, so they should be grouped under the same dissemination and reach Class_Group.

executed_decisions.new_description: Qualifiers that describe the global or large-scale spatial scope over which narratives or legends are disseminated.
executed_decisions.justification: After splitting out narrative content, this class now cleanly represents spatial scope qualifiers (e.g., 'around the world') and should be renamed and grouped accordingly.

executed_decisions.new_description: Narrative content such as stories and urban legends that are disseminated through various channels to different audiences.
executed_decisions.justification: The new split-out content class represents the narratives being disseminated and should be explicitly named and linked into the same dissemination Class_Group.
